Me da la impresión que nos van a dar una tarifa irrisoria y pues el fep es de los festivales que peor pagan, así que lo más probable es que rompa nuestro umbral de sostenibilidad, sin embargo nos gustaría expandir en nuestra escenografía para shows grandes y nos gustaría al menos ver que propuestas pueden tener. 

Si gustan envíenos un correo a balthvsmusic@gmail.com

Hello BALTHVS,

I hope the entire BALTHVS team is doing great!

I’m Andrés Moreno, founder and Creative Director of BRL Media. https://brlmedia.net/visuals/

We love working with bands and artists to create visual universes tailored to their live shows.
We’ve been involved in producing tour visuals for Feid, Andrés Cepeda, Alci Acosta, Piso 21, among others!

Do you currently work with external studios or agencies for your show visuals?

We know you’ll be performing at FEP 2025, and I’d love to connect and explore what we can create together!

O **3º Ornithos Grande Reserva Mata Atlântica** acontecerá de 14 a 16 de março de 2025 em Antonina, PR, com atividades no Teatro Municipal, Armazém Macedo e Praça Feira Mar. O evento promove a conservação ambiental e o turismo sustentável através de palestras, oficinas, saídas de campo e atividades culturais.

**Destaques:**
- Participação de ornitólogos e conservacionistas como Fernando C. Straube, Priscilla Esclarski, Carlos Borja, Fernanda Rodrigues, Ricardo Borges, João Vitor Perin Andriola e Tiago Machado, entre outras palestras.
- Observação de aves em trilhas, passeios de barco e ao amanhecer.
- Networking.
- Feira de agroecologia.
- Atividades infantis, passeio de caiaque e flutuação no rio do Nunes.

Organizado pela Leme Meio Ambiente e Cultura, Elefante Produtora e Projeto Ornithos.

I want to have an idea..! I do not have any friends down that way.  My honey bunny Kathleen and I head down there once a year to pedal bikes on the bike path between Nelsonville and Athens (Athens is pretty damn cool) - The bike trail passes 5 or 6 breweries. - If you guys all bring bikes on the road, and enjoy freshly made beers and cider, The trail would be a fun adventure. - I made up a GPS map of the trail, if you'd like a copy I'll send one.

That is demoralizing for sure! I'm glad you shared the info with me!
That's why we love Austin

We don't properly have a music scene. There are tons of music niches, metal mostly. Indie bands play frequently, but there's not an event culture yet. People hang out outside, don't buy merch, complain about ticket costs. It's difficult. Also, big events are killing small venues. It's hard.

Something about these high altitude towns where people get adjusted and routine. I dunno.

Dude...

I am ok here. Many are not. We are a transgender positive community and the current shift in politics has everyone on edge. No one knows anything yet but it works toward more public abandonment, not supportive community building we desperately need here.
Simply because they ARE modern day Albuquerque.
These kats KNOW Albuquerque. Comes out in everything they do and write. Again, without even trying to do so. They are one of my favs here. Truly.
https://open.substack.com/pub/joesmithstringer/p/the-maddening-genius-of-nara-visa?r=2ihwss&utm_medium=ios
I like this one. I wrote it about two of our most beloved humans in the scene. I think they captured the first 25 years in our new century in Albuquerque very well (without even trying to do so).
https://open.substack.com/pub/joesmithstringer/p/the-gral-brothers-volume-3-a-25-year?r=2ihwss&utm_medium=ios

Post Covid: everyone is home by 8pm; in bed by 10. Some shows don’t start til 9. Nobody goes out. Restaurants and independent retail shops are closing. Public seems checked OUT. But everybody goes through the motions and will tell you it’s all good. Everything is fine.

The Albuquerque scene???

Was once RULED by metal. Metal everywhere and every damn thing; it became a very popular touring spot in the 80’s and 90’s because of metal. Indigenous and popular hiphop had a killer underground scene here in the mid 2000’s all the way up to eh…..2012-2015. Ish.

Punk was huge here just before covid and the DIY scene was world famous. All of it gone now.

Nothing but breweries and singer songwriters killing themselves for a couple of bucks. Venues pay nothing to very little. And they get away with it due to the sheer number of artists we have here. We have a LOT!!

But the beauty here. Goes largely and sadly ignored. Propped up against the Sandia Peak, we get TWO sunsets every night when the light bounces off the rock. Most folks glass over the beauty here to point out all the things we don’t have.

We may be on the brink of a culture shift here where smaller venues and homes (like mine) become intimate listening spaces. While we wait for landlords and citizens to re-occupy their agency. I’m building a listening schedule now and we have a few promising joints in Nob Hill (the trendy area; next to UNM). 

Everything is wide open here. Artists who struggle want their validation in the form of a public support who cannot recognize them.
Artists who thrive, get OUT QUICK, and usually guts the entire town for about 6-12 months. Feels like a minor league farm here at times for musicians. And art. As such, the public views it as minor also. Ignorable.

It’s a love hate relationship for sure. Everyone struggles for identity here yet we don’t have the population density to support segregation and stuck mindsets. I fear we are on the brink of an upcoming gentrification and it’s gonna get violent. Poverty is king here and frustrations are literally pouring into the streets of downtown. Venues are stuck in the 90’s; public is justifiably AFRAID to go out at night; landlords are absent; city officials are absent. Everyone seems absent here. It has taken a toll on our human arts scene. 

Point blank: our scene is unsupported here. Despite the wide array of genre and evolution of high desert music.
Is there something you've wrote that can help us contextualize the Albuquerque scene? Would love to know more.
As an artist, I guess that’s my Albuquerque. It’s weird and broke here but we have a unique music community (very accepting). Glad to hear that’s your Austin. 🤘🏼💫

Hey there!

We are TER CO. ESTUDIO, a creative lab specializing in audiovisual projects. We’ve had the opportunity to collaborate with artists like Aterciopelados, Soy Emilia, Mediopicky, Café Tacvba, Altamirano, Nidia Góngora, King Edi K, Frente Cumbiero, and many more.

This year, we’ll be at Bahidorá, producing a short documentary capturing the festival’s essence and the journey of some of the artists performing.

We’d love to take this opportunity to collaborate with you and your team, offering a custom audiovisual content package that you can use for social media, press kits, EPKs, and more. Our package includes:

✨ What we offer:
🎥 High-quality recaps with dynamic editing and top-tier sound.
📸 Professional photography capturing your performance and behind-the-scenes moments.
⚡ Fast delivery, so you have your content ready to share.
💰 We adapt to any budget without compromising quality.

We know that festival visual coverage can be expensive or tricky to coordinate, so we’ve created an agile, affordable, and professional solution to ensure you get stunning content from your show—hassle-free.

Bahidorá is a unique experience, and we want to help you document it with the quality it deserves.

🔥 We’d love to be part of your journey! Let us tell your story.

Right now, we’re in the process of growing La Palma, building our community little by little. This project started about six months ago, and every day we’re bringing more people together, creating something special.

At this moment, bringing you all for a performance like the one you’ll be doing at Wild Buffalo would be a bit challenging for us financially. But honestly, I love your music, and I’d really love to make something happen in the future—hopefully sooner rather than later! It would be amazing to have you three at La Palma for a show.

Wishing you all the best for your event at Wild Buffalo! I know it’s going to be incredible. Much success to you! 🔥🎶

I mess around with music from time to time (nothing pro, just experimenting in my own way), and I vibe so much with your sound. I even catch myself improvising over your songs, and honestly, it’s such a cool feeling—it just flows!
It would be amazing to have you all perform with us at some point! I know your energy combined with the vibes of the place would create something truly incredible. Hope we can make it happen! 🔥🌴✨

That’s awesome! I’m from Bucaramanga, specifically from Girón, a beautiful little town nearby. I’ve been living in Bellingham for three years, and seven months ago, I started La Palma—a collective that brings people together through music, art, and Latin-Caribbean culture.

More than just a business, it’s a space where we celebrate our roots, dance, share, and create experiences that unite us

Well, Asbury Hall (also called Babeville) is a beautiful place to play. Old church purchased by Indie artist Ani Difranco who had her record label offices in the building. There’s also a cool art gallery/org houses in the building.

Buffalo Ironworks is a cool club, esp in warm weather because there’s a garage door right by the stage that opens onto an alleyway with table and chairs. Very cool. 

Town Ballroom has a great following and is one of my favorite places to see bands because of the various levels of places to stand. 

Electric City is new and pretty cool. People can reserve tables or couch areas for extra $. I was only there once.  

Can you try getting into the Newport Folk Festival? We go every year and you guys would be loved. It’s in Newport, Rhode Island.
Would love to visit soon. Where should we play!
